title: How do we build communities of trust? Is there compound-interest of knowing?
description:
Shane comes in for a convo conversation. He has such an interesting story but he doesn't want the story to take the hour. He's got questions so here we go. 

Airforce brat
Father was an outlier
Colorado springs, met shane's mom
School bus and some goats, from San Antonia to Montana, 100 acres on top of a mountain
Enough education to teach. Not a good mix. Logging community
Eureka Montana, population 300
7th day Adventist church, father trained for leadership in it, moving around
Female prophet debunked, it wrecked his faith
Left the faith, got involved in all sorts of things
Moved to Missoula, 
Mom maintained her faith because of all of that
Experience of worshipping with a black church is so much different from a Montana church
He has to be loving, he has to be able to do miracles
By 12 had been in the meaning crisis without being a victim of evil
Drugs, adult relationships early, friends of older siblings 
Got girlfriend pregnant as a sophomore in High school, 
Convince her to marry him
University of Montana
Legally divorced lost the financial aid
Vervaeke
Jordan Peterson
Don't have to betray a deep value to entertain an idea that might be contradictory
Compound interest applies in ways of knowing
It's having a dad who's been able to have a certain kind of relationship with other people
Bring the 4-P of knowing into church
Dr. Jim
How can we get people to trust each other first…
Teach people to trust and be trust-worthy
We need an economy of trust. Churches are counterfeiting the economy of trust
They are obligating people to give credit to people who are not credit worthy
Eric Weinstein super-position. 

 1. Share thoughts on how might people try to structure a trusting community
 2. When I think about my responsibility to God, what do I think that is as it relates to building a community of trust
 3. What do I think is possible within my lifetime in the age of decay

Unconditional positive regard for the human but call out and respectfully say BS

That's how you trust somebody because you see them exercise their trust in God
